paragraphs.name: 4c76
paragraphs.text: Hi, thanks for the post! Are you rate limiting based on IP address or userId only? What if the user spamming is behind a corporate firewall? Or what if they’re abusing public services (aka available w/o authentication)?

virtuals.subtitle: Also, rate-limiting is a solution, but a better solution is implementing something that detects non-browser users via things like: ability…

paragraphs.text: I am confused — How was it worthwhile to optimize 20 Mb worth of ram for a use case for 10k users? How does that not scale? What kind of QPS planning assumptions am I missing that makes that that not scale?

paragraphs.name: 4ae3
paragraphs.text: Fantastic read, thank you!

paragraphs.name: f8cb
paragraphs.text: Are you willing to share any hard numbers on how fast a write propagates across your redis instances? With the token bucket algorithm, I’d assume a client could only squeek in maybe 2 or 3 extraneous requests while the read was stale (assuming your application logic doesn’t include a throttle), but I never put it to the test 🙈

virtuals.subtitle: Python’s Redis client has support for atomic transactions now. You shouldn’t have to use Lua to get them. Not sure about other languages…

paragraphs.name: afd8
paragraphs.text: Good read, thanks!
Python’s Redis client has support for atomic transactions now. You shouldn’t have to use Lua to get them. Not sure about other languages’ libraries.

paragraphs.text: Small note: I know these are fake numbers but 4 bytes per counter * 60 counters * 10,000 users is actually ~2.4mb. Still an order of magnitude better than sliding logs, but not 2 orders.

paragraphs.name: 387b
paragraphs.text: I’m not entirely clear, however, about the sliding window implementation — it appears that you’re using the same member (“1”) for storing multiple scores (i.e. timestamps). AFAIK, this isn’t how Redis’ Sorted Set works ;)
